text: <@U28G809F1|shriharsh> has joined the channel

So after lots of consideration I think I will drop the `develop` branch. I just can't find any use for it other than slowing things down during a release or a hotfix. Also most OS libraries out there do not use a develop branch as far as I saw. I also see that it is mostly used for QA to test that everything works well together which is not useful in our case since with TDD we do make sure everything works and we don't have dedicated QA anyway
makes sense
Where are you going to put the stuff that is finished and is not released yet ?
Let’s say you are working on feature 1 2 3 for a new release, and  1 and 2 are finished you usually merge that to dev. Now you need to do a hotfix, you will branch from master
how are you planning to do this without a dev branch ?
you can have an epic or a v2 branch if you have breaking changes….
alias yolo ‘git push origin master —force'
what will be the difference on having a v2 branch against a dev branch then ?
One of them is spelt "v2", whilst the other is spelt "dev"
33% efficiency saving in chars alone!
I think of develop as a kind of dog food branch
if you have a separate release branch then most likely, your dog food is going end up being master
I guess his rationale is that having master, develop and release makes develop redundant
because feature branches off develop. Develop merges into master. Master merges into release
Hotfix branches off release -> Hotfix, merges into develop, master and release
i don’t work with release maybe that’s why :smile:
I don’t either
just master dev feature
Same here
<@U0N4RS70W> every tag marks a release
so everything without a tag is basically non-releasable
so a hotfix can easily branch off of a tag
I mean the last tagged commit
basically the develop branch is the latest commits in master that don't have a tag
that's why I don't find much reason for develop, since I can just branch off of the last tagged commit and merge that in
but I do now see what you mean, where do I merge in exactly, hmmm
<@U09T8SFG8> do you tag outside of master branch?
nope
never
then that’s where you merge?
I merge a feature into master
hotfix
i thought we were talking about hotfixes
then if I want a release I make a release-x branch from master, merge that in and tag that merge
sorry I got confused
yes you would merge on the tag
that sounds reasonable
and it's basically the same as if you had the dev branch because in the end the main pain is resolving conflicts of your hotfix with the newly added (but not released) features
<@U09T8SFG8> how big is your team?
2 for now, 4 in the near future
Yeah shouldn’t be an issue
Heck you could even get away with just having one branch
no hotfixes, no releases
no flows
just living dangerously
lol
but honestly the way I see it now it is a bit problematic for hotfixes
but in theory, everything from master needs to be deployable
so for a sprint let's say we should have a dedicated branch to branch off of
but then we end up with a renamed develop branch
I’ll explain my flow.
We mostly agree on the theory
Master is the golden good copy
when all else fails, turn to the master
master does the same as release branch. Milestone releases are done with tags
that includes major and minor. patch releases inherit commit ID
develop branches off of master and serves as dog food branch
feature then branches off of develop
it’s easier to always know that everyone will be working off of develop and working copies get merged there
hotfix branches of master and is merged into both master and develop
then everyone rebases features on develop so they get the patch
major :key: - Always rebase on to develop
hi guys, i'm try to use `TimeZone.getDefault()` to get my current timezone so that I can show timestamps correctly
but it doesnt give me the timezone i'm current be on but the UTC one
any suggestion guys? :confused:
so <@U08GFT5V5> the Gitflow model then
Close, but not quite
I see the need for hotfixes so maybe I'll go with it in the end
It’s my own derivative
because branching off of the tag and merging back into it for hotfixes looks a bit complicated
on the other hand I could have each feature branch to represent a complete feature
something that the user could use when it's finished
<@U277WVCUT|muthuraj> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/muthuraj/F28JMUT97/-.java|Untitled> and commented: <@U0KU8TDV2>  try this
well that assumes that everyone will work on the same feature
if I understand you correctly
which I think isn’t always the case
if you have people working on features in parallel, they have to converge somewhere
it's almost never the case, for now at least
<@U277WVCUT> i've tried that already, it doesnt work, in fact, the `Calendar.getInstance()` creates a `GregorianCalendar` with the `TimeZone.getDefault` under the hood, so it just doesnt work
i've tried on a Nexus 5x and an ASUS, but still the same, hopefully it's not device-specific

I also have forks. So for me is master beta dev feature1_QA feature1_Fork. So i work on my feature1_fork, when is done i make PR to feature1_QA, is code reviewed, if everything is OK, then it’s merged and QA pick that branch, if it is ok is merged into dev. We have a beta branch so usually we go from dev to beta with their own tags. And from  beta to master having master their own tags. Hotfixes go from master
<@U0N4RS70W> I see that working quite well for big teams
yeah we are 5 android devs + 2 external ones

Has anyone ever seen this kind of issue before… I have a POJO which has four `List<OtherPOJO> myList1 = new ArrayList<>()` on debug builds, I get the expected myList1.size() = 0 but on release builds, I get a NPE on myList1. Using retrofit2 + gson 2.7
yeah i have seen many time this kind of NPE
i endup checking not null every place.. or atleast some place i had create getter setter which take care of this
this issue normally i see when app running outofmemory or app instance was in background and taken to foreground after a while like 2-3 hours etc
I do have getter/setter methods but I rather not check for null then set to empty list. It seems like gson is deserializing differently based on the build type.
i never seen the issue while developing or testing but i have seen this crash from production builds
at some point we were 100% sure that it should never be null logically and theoretically but then also we get NPE crash..
i guess someone here told me that Rxjava or Kotlin can solve this all NPE issues
NPE is likely proguard related
<@U05473HHT> are you marking them with @SerializedName annotation?
We do have proguard setup but I call all the methods in this POJO through out the app, so I don’t see why it would be stripped out.
look at the compiled code and check
No, I don’t have that annotation on them since they are the same name as what the JSON returns.
well put it
I’ll try adding the annotation to see if that helps at all.
most likely proguard
your models are most likely being renamed
so json deserialization fails
add the annotation @SerializedName(“json_item_name”) since otherwise as ian and nish said, proguard swallows your models and spits them out
We have proguard setup to not obfuscate.
It still minifies i think
probably
Adding the @SerializedName annotation didn’t fix it.
hmmm does the JSON actually contain that item?
does your release build target a different end point
<@U0548MM6B> the JSON will return the item if it has it, otherwise it won’t which is why I just want to set it to an empty list.
That feeling where product flavours and build types finally make sense
My god
I just checked with ClassyShark to see if proguard was stripping anything out of my POJOs and it is not.
<@U05473HHT> @Expose annotation?
I do have @Expose annotation
As they said, is release pointing to a different end point which is returning null?
Thus setting list to null
No release and dev endpoints return the same json structure. I’m only able to reproduce this issue if I do a release build of the app.
No I get that
But I've had an issue lately where the API will return `null` instead of an empty array
What's the config difference?
release just runs proguard
Do it in debug
And check
I have the release config set as debuggable true
Nah run proguard w debug ans see if it's happening
Set the debug to run proguard
do you get the issue if you turn off proguard in release?
Okay, so it is likely a proguard issue… If I have proguard on debug then I can reproduce this issue.
Now just to find what it is
I’ll have to figure out the proguard rule to add but it doesn’t make sense since I just followed what we do in other parts of our app and don’t have issues there.
it think if you look at your compiled code the issue will be clear
I did with ClassyShark and all the POJOs that I’m having issues with all look fine.
Actually, looking again, the compiled code doesn’t have the `= new ArrayList<>();` which is the issue I’m having.
:wink:
check the constructor though
it ‘shouldnt’ be deleting things that would be strange
I figured things out, thanks for the help everyone!
<@U05473HHT> :taco:
<@U05473HHT>  what was the problem?
Don’t just leave without telling us the solution
<@U08GFT5V5> it was a proguard issue so I just needed to add a rule to keep my class.
Speaking of proguard, maybe someone here can help with this other issue I put on the back burner...

I have an app that uses a library which defines a bunch of Activitiy in the library AndroidManifest.xml so during manifest merger, they all get added into my app. However, in my own AndroidManifest.xml, I set it up to remove the Activity I don’t use. Now I’m trying to figure out a way to have the shrinkResources + minifyEnabled to remove those Activity + resources since I don’t use them.

please how do i consistently manage or delete things from SQLite database... for instance
If i have a user_details table,
i need to sometimes clear the db, its more like how instagram works, 
when i click on a user profile it loads it first time and save it on the DB,
but the next time it views without re-loading, more like a cache,
